title: Gotham Knights
review:
Now, bear in mind: I got this game dirt cheap. Right off the bat, my first piece of advice to you is not to get it for full price. Maybe when it's off by 50% or more. Because when "Gotham Knights" is fairly priced, it's honestly quite an enjoyable time. Oh, and yes: you can play the entire game solo. 

Now, full disclosure: I love the Batman Arkham games and Red Hood is one of my favorite DC characters, so that certainly helped me get over some of the glaring flaws in this title. But I won't shy away from admitting that those exist and are quite annoying at times. Even with that, though, when Gotham Knights works it becomes really fun. 

Is it more fun than any of the Arkham games that came before it? No. Not by a long shot. And I'm one of the guys that thinks that "Arkham Knight" is underrated, so you can imagine.

Okay, then, let's start with the good. The art direction in this game is fantastic. We've got good ol' gloomy Gotham, but bathed in neon, which is a great idea, honestly. Then we've got the main cast: great character designs and awesome costumes. Voice acting is great, but the writing really, really brings it down. I'll phrase it like this: have you watched "Arrow"? Do you know how that show is sometimes written in a turbo-cringe way, but it remains enjoyable because it is charming? Well, here it's the same, but without any of the charm. You've got the whole schtick: from forced inclusivity all the way to self-serving plot elements. 

Other than that, though, the story itself -- as an idea -- is great. It's not executed in the best of ways, sure, and any one among you that has been a Batman fan for at least five minutes would see where it's going about 4 hours in, but hey: I appreciate the effort. The important thing is that the game is fun to play. I mean, sometimes.

Okay, okay, here's the problems: characters get stuck on everything. Moves don't connect properly. Abilities sometimes trigger, other times don't, and then sometimes they also miss entirely. Heavy attacks with some characters are utterly pointless. City navigation, with some characters, is incredibly dull and boring. Figuring out what to do, sometimes, is exceptionally difficult. And, of course, the very fact that this game was built multiplayer-first is an issue to the extent where I absolutely wish it was not. 

Oh, and textures fail to load-in properly half the time, which results in a mix of HD and SD content that looks, well… Unique. 

So, have you played any of the Arkham games? You know how you feel in total control of Batman? Well, here it's not the case. In fact, far from it. When it works, it feels like a broken Arkham game, when it does not: it's a pain. But something in my broken brain was okay with that. Whether it was because I like the games that came before this one or due to the core gameplay loop being fun: I honestly cannot be sure. 

There's a lot to do in this game. Levelling up and unlocking gear is fun. The provided skill trees are utterly pointless, so you'll probably forget that they even exist. The very idea of a progression system, however, carries that extra bit of satisfaction. Unfortunately, there is content locked behind levels and gear requirements and I just didn't partake in any of it. 

"Gotham Knights" isn't a bad idea, but it's a bad execution. If it was built like a proper Arkham game from the ground up, I have no doubt in my mind that it would've been a ton more fun. That being said: it is still a good time for Batman nerds and Arkham fans. If anything, this title proves that there is certainly an  audience for spinoff Arkham games. So long as they are single-player and their content isn't locked behind a poorly designed progression system. 

On a personal level, I think that Red Hood’s campaign here does the character service. And that’s a tough thing to do, considering what DC has done to Jason in the past. He’s not always written well, but ultimately he gets a nice, neat character ark that just feels proper after the events of “Arkham Knight”.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
[h1]Triple U gaming Unfinished, unbalanced and underwhelming[/h1]

[b]Gotham Knights[/b] is a bit of a let down with huge potential to be somewhat actually good but it’s not. It almost feels like it got [i]rushed down the pipeline[/i] and THAT can be easily felt within the first hour of gameplay [5 years+ of the development *cough*]. 

[h3]GK[/h3] on its own is a [u]first iteration[/u] of DC universe 'open world' with [b]co-op[/b]: where you can [u]team up[/u] with your IRL friends and family to 'fight evil and corruption' of the Gotham city. The roster of toons you can play as is limited to: 
‘Bratty’ [b]Bat Girl[/b] and three Robins from current: ‘Smol geeky’ [b]Robin[/b] (R3), ‘Leadership guru’ [b]Nightwing[/b] (R2) and ‘Me smash/shoot’ [b]Red hood[/b] (R1). 

[h3]Gotham city[/h3] layout and [u]overall[/u] atmosphere setup is extremely good [b]10/10[/b] eye candy level of detail and immersion with tall buildings to climb on, gliding around it just feels right - you’re in actual Gotham!  Alternatively each member of the ‘team batman’ gang gets a fancy futuristic motorbike and further down the story ability to fast travel via tech provided by [spoiler]Lucius Fox[/spoiler]. 

And here it goes [i]down the hill[/i].. City is [u]empty[/u] and completely [b]soulless[/b], road traffic is poor, interaction with NPCs lacks lustre and cringe at best. Every flipping car you will see in game has [b]tinted[/b] windows and are [i]indestructible[/i] - yes you can’t even pop a tire with your ranged attack because why bother with [u]basic immersion 101[/u]. Up to the point that if you obstruct a patch of car or a [u]TRAIN[/u] it will just.. stop and [b]honk[/b] at you.. That’s literally it. 

[h3]Story[/h3] is mediocre-good without spoilers: It is an enjoyable experience with a few hiccups down the line - looking at you [b]Sweet Baby[/b] *cough* nevertheless, a solid [b]7/10[/b] for what we get out of it.

[h3]Combat[/h3] is slightly worse than you would expect from this genre but I’ll take it [b]6/10[/b] feels a bit like this meant to be a mobile title to begin with..

[b]Bugs..[/b] are frequent.. from your character glitching into objects, new waves of enemies not spawning properly and getting stuck in doorways to the game simply deciding to randomly crash because.. because [b]I’M BATMAN![/b] [b]4/10[/b] - Unfinished and untested.

[b]Crafting[/b] and gear acquisition is an utterly [u]unbalanced[/u] cluster duck with such a small attention to character progression that in some cases you will craft your new shiny equipment just to realise down the road that 30 seconds later you will get a new item that outperforms it.. [b]With[/b] the true end game gear hidden behind [u]extremely repetitive grind fest[/u] that we all gamers love.. [b]3/10[/b]

[b]Overall[/b] selling point and why I am playing it.. is [u]co-op[/u] and gorgeous city. So in brief summary: [i]It's a social beat 'em up to have a laugh with a friend and take screenshots.[/i] 

Generous 5/10 Can't recommend.. but it's playable.

title: Gotham Knights
review: The story is solid but the gameplay is incredibly stale and doesn't even remotely compare to the previous Arkham games. If you got it through Humble Bundle like me or can find it cheap *cough* keys for this are $3 *cough* it's worth blazing through. Fair warning, all of the post-game content revolves around heroic assaults, which are team raids similar to MMOs and Monster Hunter but the game is pretty dead. To complete them you'll have to be really geared/good or find a few friends who are willing to help you out because it's a spongefest.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
It's a hollow product that should have stayed in the oven for at least two more years - I went into the game knowing full well it was bad, still I was surprised in both good and bad ways. 

Let's start with the good things: amazing aesthetic of city design, good looking suits and touching side story sequences. The design team did their job wonderfully and gave us a Gotham design that's almost on par with Arkham Knight's Gotham. Still it lacks substance - the staggering absence of details around the city, and the unvaried building structures.

The real downsides of Gotham Knights are many, namely the horrendous gameplay, bad story progression, uncreative and repetitive side activities, etc. Its combat takes away all the things that made Batman Arkham games great, and gives us a jankier Sleeping Dogs. Sometimes it's required to do Ubisoft-styled missions in order to progress story, meaning you have to find "clues" or interrogate thugs through random events. The story progression system is truly evolving backwards. The batcycle is slow AF, the game has to add a wind blowing filter to make it look fast lol. There're also a tons of what I consider to be minor issues, like NPCs repeat lines way too often, NPC models vanish soon as enter a camera blind spot.

All those I can still endure. But my current biggest gripe with it is the the genuinely unfun experience resulting from a combination of widely scattered side activities and severely downgraded (from the Batman Arkham games) traversal system. Gliding and grappling speed is somewhere between Arkham City and Knight, but the traversal as a whole feels wrong on many level - there's no physics or a good sense of control to it. And the lack of detail in Gotham only makes going around the map even worse. 

TL;DR - the design dev team is 9/10 but the gameplay dev team is 5/10

title: Gotham Knights
review:
[h1]Superheroes in training[/h1]

An experience that might be enjoyable with a coop partner, but not worth it if you are going solo.

Repetitiveness is the keyword. There are many activities or "patrols" as they call them, to gain levels and grind materials for equipment crafting. They all turn out pretty much samey, in that it all ends in an all out brawl, pummeling enemies that feel like punchbags, soaking a lot of damage. Yet these patrols are short and way too simplistic in design. More handcrafted experiences would've been nice. It felt like a copy-paste each night.

Without knowing the actual intent of the designers, it felt like one of those MMORPGs that has daily quests, battlepasses and artificially increasing the length of the game by making the materials scarce and random, all with uninspired, monotonous gameplay.

Although with a coop partner all that grinding would be less annoying. I was joined by a random person online, and it was nice playing with someone. It made fighting a lot more easier, but like other coop games, it would shine if it were someone you knew or had the courage to talk online, coordinating attacks, strategies and overall hanging out as vigilantes, I guess. I'm just a very socially awkward introvert.

There are many things that I don't like in this game, for example, the speed is super weird. It is slow; the bike moves slowly through the city, yet there are effects layered on that should make it look faster, and that confuses my brain. The characters movement is lighter, yet heavy at the same time. I don't feel like they hit the right notes there. It is weird, because they already found the secret sauce in the Arkham Trilogy, in which Batman, and also the other characters, Batgirl, Harley Quinn, Catwoman, and I think there were more, but can't remember, they felt solid, yet agile enough to feel good to control.

Another thing that got in my nerves, especially because combat is such a big thing and you do it so often, the camera just doesn't work. Sometimes it goes crazy, fights your manual override, doesn't know where to focus and I'm pretty sure, intentionally creates blind spots.

On the positive side, I think that the main story was decent, the roster of characters is nice, I really liked to see the interactions between the Batfamily members, and grew fond of Jason Todd, of whom I only had little to no knowledge. It didn't feel at all like the main cast were simple characters, it felt like they had complex and developed identities.

Also, there were, would I say, side-main-quests? involving Harley Quinn, Mr. Freeze and Clayface with their own storyline, I guess. Albeit I didn't do them, these would extend the gameplay time and enjoyment of said activities, especially if you were to play with a coop partner.

[h3]Final thoughts[/h3]
All in all it's a decent game, although pretty grindy. The gameplay loop ended up very repetitive and annoying on the long run, which is why after the first couple of hours, I decided that I'd speedrun the game, because I wanted to see the story to its conclusion. I barely managed to keep up until the end. If it were any other world, I would've quit a long time ago. I wouldn't recommend it if you are going to play it solo. With a coop partner and a good sale, I would say go for it.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
The combat is not that smooth and advanced as in Arkham Series, but as its own title it's a great action RPG from the Batman universe. After all the patches games runs very well without any stutters even with RT enabled. Gameplay may feel little bit clunky and slow from the beginning, but after  some leveling up and unlocking skills for your character, it will get much better. 

Story and character development is very good.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I wish there was a thumbs-sideways button.

This game has a lot of good things going for it. I will admit it seems like it's mostly made for multiplayer, but I'm a soloist. With that said, there are many well-thought-out play mechanics with a unique fighting system and upgrades, and the ability to craft suits and mods for your suit SEEMS like a good idea, but I feel the crafting is very poorly executed. I do like all the variations and elemental effects and whatnot, but it is very confusing when I get blueprints (blueprints for batsuits are dropped by enemies or something???) and I'm not sure why it's necessary to have just a ton of useless things.

The main story's very good. But I wouldn't have chosen that voice for Bruce Wayne, or Batman, or Jason Todd.

The random emails are strange and all the notifications for the hundreds of things that get updated all the time, like emails, crafting items / materials, etc. And idk, but I feel like Jason Todd wouldn't ever go to a gay pride parade in costume to help celebrate. Like, I really don't feel that would be his style at all. Idk, maybe that's just me.

I've played enough of this game by now that I'm hooked by the story, and can appreciate the fighting moves and so forth and how challenging the boss fights can be, but as a whole I just don't like it. Again, just wish there was a thumbs-sideways button.

UPDATE: Now that I've finished the game, there were some veritable ups and downs in both gameplay and story. I'm sure the experience is better for multi-player players than for a soloist. I played entirely as Batgirl so only know that side of things, but still, I think overall I'd give it these kinds of scores:

5/5 replayability and collections (counting history of structures / etc)
4/5 main story (some things didn't make sense if not playing with others)
3/5 abilities / leveling up system
1/5 suit customization
1/5 weapon customization
2/5 for alignment / believability of characters (including but not limited to being able to hit / run over citizens w/out penalty (from what I could tell), etc)
2/5 for sidequests in the city
2/5 for side villain missions (could have been a chapter or so deeper, one in particular was extremely buggy for me)

So yeah like around a 2 or 3 out of 5 overall for me.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Unfortunately, this game is soulless. It feels like a mediocre live service game trapped inside a bad Arkham game. 

The characters and the writing is okay, the issue is the gameplay. In the Arkham games, you had Batman and all his upgrades and abilities and it felt cool walking and gliding across the city, taking down criminals through various creative ways, hiding in the shadows. Now you have to upgrade four character simultaneously who all play worse than the aforementioned protagonist and the combat is incredibly boring and repetitive for all of them. There aren't really cool abilities and the combat system is somehow worse now, with some abilities completely not working, like a chain attack break or the perfect combos for Red Hood. If the enemies shoot at you and you are in the open you might as well give up. You can't use gadgets during combat (you can throw stuff, but it feels like sneezing on the enemy) making every encounter very samey.

Traversing the city is equally boring. First because the grapple system is infinitely worse than gliding, which sadly only one character can do. Architecture wise, the game is a set back as well, gone is the awesome gothic-noir aesthetic. Now the city looks like your standard US city at night, that's not interesting or engaging to look at and every single area looks the same. Whose idea was it to make everything bland? There are civilians now in Gotham, but they don't interact with you and they aren't used in creative ways. The map is also gigantic, with mostly empty spaces. I much preferred the smaller, but incredibly tightly designed layout of Arkham City, where every area was used for some creative storytelling bit.

The game just feels wrong. Like they initially wanted to make an Avengers like looter shooter game, but then pivoted to a linear story, and forgot to adjust the UI or the game design. Like upgrades only apply in the main safe house. Why? The map barely has things happening and you constantly have to ride your motorcycle through empty roads to get to anywhere. But why bother? The encounters are not interesting, the dialogue of thugs is generic, there is no diegetic storytelling through missable thug dialogue, like before.

All this could be forgiven, but the controls are so bad, I lost the majority of my fights because my character just wouldn't respond to a button press properly. Like whose idea was to have the jump button on shift? Except it's not really a jump, unless you are next to wall. But if you are next to rail, it could also mean, you jump over it, right into the enemies. Most areas are not designed with combat in mind, so you get stuck in geometry constantly. Combos are not interesting to maintain and it's impossible to target enemies during combat, so if some thug is preparing to shoot at you, and you want to batarang him, your character will likely just throw a batarang to somewhere off screen. 

I thought, playing the game a bit and trying out the heroes would be fun, but at some point I realized I wasn't having any fun here. The story is the only okay element. Feels more like committee design.

title: Gotham Knights
review: "It was a good game with an engaging world, but the plot was too weak. The first 3-4 hours of the game were enjoyable, and the Harley Quinn mission was particularly good (the background score for that mission was excellent). However, too many side missions may slow down the pace of the game, and, as usual, revenge and betrayal play a significant role in the pre-climax. I played it with Red Hood, However, other characters felt weak in comparison. Ultimately, it's your choice which character to play, but the ending was open and lacked a clear conclusion, which was quite disappointing. The experience will be better if you play on medium to hard settings, as the game could become easy if you focus too much on side missions. The OST is good overall. If you enjoy the world, that might outweigh any concerns."

title: Gotham Knights
review:
After 100% this game, I can confidently say that after the story this game becomes pure misery to complete.

The DLC is not fun, 250 crimes is terrible, and when the game bugged out I wanted take a sledgehammer to my nuts because that would have been more enjoyable.

If you just want to play for the story it's okay but nothing to rave about.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Bought this at a discount along with Suicide Squad and unfortunately had to refund both. After refunding Suicide Squad I thought and hoped that this would be better, and it is, but it wasn't enough for me. The combat is absolutely rubbish compared to the Arkham games, Mad Max and Shadow of Mordor games. 

The cutscenes are amazing and the Batman vs Ra's al Ghul intro really made me hope that I would get hooked, but I didn't because so many important systems of the game just didn't work for me: 

Combat: Like I said, crap compared to these games: Arkham games, Mad Max and the Shadow of Mordor. 

Traversal: Traversing is one of the highlights in the Arkham series and here it feels so bad.  The "good" character traversalsystem you have to unlock (wtf?) + The bike feels like a tank and develops no sense of speed while driving. 

Gear system: This actually killed the game for me. Who in the *f-ing* world thought it was a good idea to put a gear system a la Destiny into a superhero game? yeah -> this was definitely the deathblow for me. 

On the bright side: I want to replay the Arkham games and finish Mad Max. 

I really hope that those two games were just an accident of corporate greed and that they'll never do anything like that again and that the next one will be something great again. 

#MakeSuperheroGamesGreatAgain

title: Gotham Knights
review:
More of a first impressions than a review.  
Great opening cinematic and sequence to get started...when the proper game began I felt overwhelmed by information and tutorials while also not understanding what the game wanted from me or where to go. 

Probably spent a third of this playtime finding the back entrance to the GCPD.  I thought I stopped two crimes on Day 1 but the summary screen came up with zero.  I don't get why.   Moving around the city feels awkward compared to Arkham games.  There's just way too much going on with the level up screens and quests screens and all that interface.  

I was confused while also not having much fun and the games negative reputation means I don't want to bother sticking with this.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Gotham Knights, the game where you don’t get to be Batman but instead play as his lovable understudies. Think of it as the superhero version of being handed a salad when you ordered a steak—it’s technically food, but it’s not what you wanted.

The game sets up an intriguing premise: Gotham without Batman. But the city itself doesn’t feel drastically different from what we’ve seen in the Arkham games. Sure, the criminals are getting bolder, but the absence of Batman doesn’t feel as world-shaking as you’d expect. Instead, Gotham remains more or less the same chaotic place, only now with four caped crusaders instead of one..

Playing Gotham Knights is like stepping into a pair of oversized Batman boots—except they don’t fit right, and you keep tripping over yourself. Combat is fine, the fluidity of Arkham Knight's combat is gone, replaced with a more simplified, button-mashy style that’s serviceable but less refined. Sure, you’ve got different playstyles with the four Knights—Batgirl’s hacking, Robin’s stealth, Nightwing’s agility, and Red Hood’s raw power—but none of them quite capture the poetic brutality of Arkham's free-flow fighting. The problem is that every time you punch a bad guy, you can’t help but think, “Batman would’ve done that cooler.”

Gotham Knights swaps out gliding for a Batcycle, which is kind of like trading a jet engine for a moped. The Batcycle gets the job done, but it’s not the most exciting ride. And while each Knight does have their own unique traversal abilities (Batgirl can glide like Batman, Nightwing has a Fortnite glider, Robin teleports, and Red Hood jumps around like an angry superhuman), it lacks the thrilling simplicity of Batman’s cape-glide and grapple combo. The movement feels more clunky and less like you’re a stealthy creature of the night.

Gotham City looks fantastic, as it always does, but it’s less “living, breathing city” and more “superhero theme park”. Everywhere you turn, there’s a conveniently placed group of thugs just waiting for a beatdown.  The side quests are... there. Solve crimes, beat up people, rinse, repeat. But what truly stands out is how every crime feels like the same crime, just copy-pasted into different alleys. I mean, if you’ve fought one Gotham thug, you’ve fought them all. Even the goons look like they’re unionized into using the same 3 wardrobe sets.

Gotham Knights is fun in its own right—especially with the co-op aspect—but it lacks the refined combat, thrilling traversal, and immersive world that made Arkham Knight so iconic. If you go into the game expecting Batman: Arkham Knight 2, you’re setting yourself up for disappointment.

title: Gotham Knights
review: i got so into the game i stayed up to 1 in the morning...i have work at 8. the game was very immersive, i wasn't too sure who to play at first but ended up going with Batgirl and honestly was a lot of fun. the controls took a lot of getting used too many times instead of pressing X i pressed C. I particularly liked the training aspect of the game especially at the start, i panicked and just button mashed my way through. all in all i really like the game.

title: Gotham Knights
review: How the hell did they ruin the amazing combat system? I know they are another studio, but how do you turn an amazing combat system into a battle system as fluid as lego blocks. God this is awful. The only cool thing about this game is the costumes and visuals of the heroes, nothing else. I got this game for dirt cheap, like sub $5 and I still think its a waste of money.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I don't like it. It's like devs took all the mechanics from the Arkham series, stripped everything fun from them and slapped annoying "game as a service" elements. It just feels like a waste of time. You would get a much, MUCH better game by stripping these annoying systems. What we've got is a boring game that for some people will be too exhausting to even finish it. 

Just take a look at some examples why this game does not respect your time:
- separated equipment for each character 
- You have to craft equipment for each character separately 
- As in some kind of mmo game, you collect resources to craft equipment in the first place
- You get better equimpent but at the same time enemies scale as the game goes by, so you don't really feel more and more powerful. You simply craft better equipment to keep up with the enemy scaling
- Hundreds of useless "challenges" (game as a service elements) to unlock, or get things, like for example - beat 5 enemies with shield, make a 10 perfect dodges and so one
- Randomly generated events just for the sake of letting you grind resources
- Each missions have activities with optional subtasks that usually require more time spend for just a few more resources gains
- Very slow running animations,
- Very slow bike speed
- There is no point of trying to be sneak, because many events you can just brute force (it's also usually much quckier this way)
- You have 4 characters but from practical perspective they are the same in the long run. Just a slightly different dialogues, animations and some special skills that most of the time you won't use it anyway.
-  Too many collectibles. In previous games at least games, you had a system for finding easily and they required you to do something - simple puzzle to make them more exciting. Here? You need to find on google guide, find collectible on the map and press interaction button to pick it up, that all. So much fun when you need to repeat this more than 150 times (amount of collectibles in game).
- Unlocking fast traver requires the hardest thing that you can imagine - finding the drone and waiting. There is no puzzle, no fight, just find the dron, scna it and wait.
- You need to do random looking events to move the story further


Even if it's supposed to be the reboot or something, it does not matter as game is just simply below average and much worse than the Arkham series.

Not to even mention taht there are other problems with this game:
- stealth is much simplier (there are no gadgets to use), so it gets boring quickly especially when you will find out that most of the time you can just use brute force (engage standard combat)
- Traversal is less fluid - no cape to fly, slow vehicles, annoying fast travel unlocks
- Graphically it's ok, but I prefer better design instead of boring graphical fidelity
- You often have to go back to the main base. Not only because for the sake of pushing the story further, but also for crafting purposes (you can't craft new equimpments anywhere else). In those cutscenes, you just listening boring dialogues. Can't they just use radio communications for that?
- The combat system is simplified compared to the Arkham series, and is probably broken because of the poorly implemented game as service elements. It's less fun, and you can often cheese it by just shooting enemies from a distance (of course if you hame high enough weapon crafted)
- UI/menu design. This is related to game as a services. I suspect there were a bigger plans for this system, but I guess after seeing how much of a success was Marvel's Avengers game, they've decided to tone down those elements.

The main story looks interesting, but I have no strength to reach the end due to gameplay.

From technical perspective. Game is CPU bound/hungry (especially in the open world), but overall it's fluid, like incredibly fluid especially taking into consideration that game is running on Unreal Engine 4 that is famous for stuttering. However, the game have poorly implemented draw distance. It's distracting when driving motorbike (although this could also be due to me installing mod for faster motorbike)

title: Gotham Knights
review: Now I did get this game on sale mind you, but Im honestly having a blast. The game really does have some jank, especially with movement and it can get repetitive if you play a long session, but the main gameplay loop of going around beating up bad guys is fun. I'm also enjoying the story its just as cheesy as any DC movie and the main premise is interesting. I don't know what the game was like when it came out 2 years ago to a lot of negative reviews but i'd give it a try now, its pretty fun, and even better if you can snag it on a discount.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I'm normally not a fan of superheroes, in general, but I'm loving the game-play--going out on night patrol as Batgirl and learning to fight better. There's some wonderful tactical moves to be made and the animations are a joy to watch as she kicks a Freak's head to the ground after a perfect evade. 

I read reviews both positive and negative before I buy a product. Now that I've put in a reasonable amount of game-play, I'm baffled by the profusion of negative reviews. I find this game addictive and quite enjoyable, and in addition to the fighting, the story helps draw me in further. I personally find the many negative reviews unwarranted. 

Is the game without flaws? Of course not, but they are minor, in my opinion, and almost unnoticeable. I'm attempting to find some scathing criticism about the game that would reflect the criticism of the many negative reviews. Perhaps, the common routine of the night patrol can lead to boredom, but so far I enjoy flying above the incredible city of Gotham, and then swooping down upon an unsuspecting goon with a takedown. Or doing a wheelie on the Batcycle and then ejecting from it into the middle of a pack of Regulators with my sensually-tight oufit, raw superhero energy, batarang, and playful banter.

Each game has an arc of entertainment and Gotham Knights will continue to give me quite a few more hours of play. As well, I'm looking forward to sharing the game with my nephew in cooperative. 

On sale, an obvious deal. At full price, that's questionable. I'd wait for another sale just in case your expectations, and what you find fun, is different than mine.

Batgirl rocks!

8 out of 10

title: Gotham Knights
review: Better than expected. Smooth performance, good mission design and beautiful Gotham. Combat a bit lacking and repetitive. Still fine for a discounted game.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Allows you to immerse yourself in a story playing your favorite characters. The design makes each character unique in it's abilities and play style. Allows for you and your friends to roam the mean streets of Gotham and fight crime together. Very well done story lines that keep you interested.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Its a really nice game. Combat is kinda slow and non gratifying. Wish the combat switched up a little bit like spider man. Half the time I'm just spamming the left mouse button and then the fights over. The best thing about this game I would say is the multiplayer feature. I can protect Gotham with my brother, and its a lot of fun.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
The game is fun in concept and is good for about an hour, however, at random intervals, the game will just close to your desktop and you'll have to open it all up again. This crashing bug seems to be common with people suggesting that "the integrity of the game files must be corrupt" or "your drivers on your PC must be out of date", but seeing as though I've faced this issue many times with this game and have verified the integrity of the game files through steam multiple times, and seeing how I've checked my drivers and forcibly updated them through Nvidia's updater every time there's a new update and I still run into this crashing problem, I Cannot In Good Faith recommend this game...

I would be okay with just opening the game, rolling a D6 and potentially getting the 1 in 6 chance of it starting, and getting through the menus, and launching the game world, and opening cut-scenes, even though rolling a D6 and calling the roll correctly that many times is ridiculously unlikely, I'd still play the game, IF it wasn't for the game's anti-theft/cheat protocol where by IF you open your game too many times within the same day (for any reason like, I don't know, the game Randomly crashing at every turn), you are BANNED from even trying to launch the game at all for the next 24 hours, even though you paid money for this game and you should have some kind of right to not be restricted from a product you bought.

Ignoring the whole glaring issue of the game flow randomly being interrupted by freak-spontaneous crashes (with not a single error report btw...) and the absolutely horrible implementation of this anti-theft/cheat feature, the game itself and story wise is great.
We get to see a great amount of big baddies from the DC Universe, the difficulty (even on its highest setting) isn't impossible and playing with friends is a damned hoot. The loot/gear system is really nice and the cut-scenes are fun to watch, making the game fairly well paced. Just don't expect to actually play the game once you've downloaded it and be prepared for being soft-banned for 24 hours on random days because you launched your game too many times after it crashed for no explainable reason...

title: Gotham Knights
review: Disappointing that the base for a possibly great game is there, but the idiocy of trying to force live-service ruined it. Buy on huge discount

title: Gotham Knights
review: I've put a few hours into this game to give it chance and gotten through the opening barrage of missions and open-world sections, and my initial impression is... not great. A certain portion of the inevitable backlash to this game was always going to be its inevitable comparison to the Arkham games, but it does beg the question of why this game seems to have learned next to nothing from those games. Doing anything in this game feels like walking through a room with the stickiest floor you've ever been on. The foot traversal, vehicles, combat, dialogue, etc. all feel... "sticky" in a way that makes me slightly uncomfortable to experience. I might update this if I come back to give it a little more time, but I don't see my opinion of this game improving as I play more.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Great fun to be had in multiplayer, single player is awesome as well. This deserves good reviews so unsure why there are such bad ones, dont be put off as this is a great game.

title: Gotham Knights
review: its a good game 10/10 if u just want a game to hangout with Ur friends 110% recommend and if u wanna fight crime with them to 1000% recommend such a good game gonna play again

title: Gotham Knights
review: Game is fun, I've been playing a lot and I think it gets way less credit than it deserves.

title: Gotham Knights
review: the story is cool, the combat is smooth, and the graphics are great. 10/10, love it!

title: Gotham Knights
review: Game has gotten a bad rap but is a pretty solid Batman-ish game. It is nowhere near the polish of previous titles but the loop is fun and I'm having a good time with the story.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
It's astonishing to me that games like this get poor reviews. This is a great game. It looks gorgeous. It plays well. It's very immersive. There's plenty of action to be had. I can't understand why people are becoming more and more difficult to please. 

This game's a very good game. Give it a shot.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
So far the game is really good, the graphics are ok, the combat is also good and the map is quite big with a lot of sights. The one thing I think needed more time to work on is traveling mechanics because I feel like they are too slow, even the bike is feeling slow. One thing this game amazed me compared to other Arkham Games or Batman Movies is how it made Bruce feel like a human in his left audio files, I didn't feel his human side anywhere like they did here, so far this is my favorite side objective.And I also love how the characters look, very well made models and I appreciate that. I still have quite a lot to play but good job so far, I'll update the review at a later date.
UPDATE: I have finished the game on main story and New Game + and I loved the story, the side objectives were a bit boring but still ok in the first playthrough but in new game plus doing everything again got me bored really fast, the collectibles were nice and the movement improved in game once you unlock fast travel so it helps in that regard. I have to mention I disliked Heroic Assault, too grindy and no players to do it with.
In my opinion the game is a must play, it's not perfect but let's be honest it's better than some other stuff you can find out there but the msrp the game launched at was a bit much, I think 40$ for this is the sweet spot that is should've launched at and around 30$ with discounts.

title: Gotham Knights
review: ngl the game is over-hated, if you're a fan of DC and especially the Bat-Family this is a no brainer when the game is on sale. combat and leveling up is quite fun but the game is still flawed, ESPECIALLY the dialogue

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Holy sh1t this game is BORING. 

Just mind-numbing encounters and then an actual mission in between. On top of that, a garbage, uninspired loot/crafting system that is just insulting. Combat is okay.

My expectations were low and I'm still disappointed. 
Shoutout to the devs, im sure this isnt nearly what they envisioned.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Got it for dirt cheap and it's eh,but the game itself is way worse than batman arkham series.

title: Gotham Knights
review: there's no way that every single fucking time I enter a vent during a story mission, I get stuck in it.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Got it from Humble Choice. It is nice hero game with its positives and negatives.

title: Gotham Knights
review: I honestly really love this game! I love the different story lines and how they're all kind of interconnected in some ways. I also love the ability to play as all 4 of these characters. Typically you don't get a lot of play with Nightwing, Batgirl, Red Hood and Tim Drake's Robin, and the ability to play as all 4 of these characters has been amazing!

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I struggled reviewing this game because I loved it. The combat, the story, the characterisation, all of it was incredible! Right up until the end where they spat in your face for investing in the game with an inconclusive, rushed ending. It literally felt like they got to the halfway point and said "ehh can't be bothered to do anymore, let's end it here". There is NO conclusion. You actually end up doing nothing of importance throughout the whole story! 

Such a shame because the story was very unique! And all the characters were spot on! And the concept of a world without Batman, watching the knights go through mourning, was very moving! So if you want to experience some cool semi-Arkham style gameplay and have fun with friends, I'd get this game. If you're super into Batman and want this for the plot... just go play the Arkhamverse.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I really want to like this game. I love collectathons and especially the Batman games. The city and scenery are very well done. The story is okay though not too compelling.

But the movement is so sluggish and unresponsive in this title, it makes combat frustrating. Sometimes in order to do an action I have to spam the button for 2-4 seconds until it finally registers (say, drop down from a ledge). This unresponsiveness can make combat quite irritating in moments especially on higher difficulties. You also have to make sure you stop moving about 1-2 seconds before you actually want to stop due to the unresponsiveness. It never really feels like I'm in control of my movement.

The camera angles are rough as well. In the middle of combat I am frequently blinded by my camera squishing into a wall if I get too close to buildings and such. And aiming with the grappling hook often makes no sense. When standing still and about to grapple it will suddenly aim somewhere else last moment, usually some ledge very high right above me. Which is unfortunate because besides the motorcycle/fast travel for longer distances your main way of getting around is grappling from building to building. It feels like a slower, worse Spiderman in that sense, especially with the near useless travel powers each hero gets.

I found myself wanting to quit more than keep playing so I decided to uninstall and leave my play through where it is. Maybe I'll pick it up again one day but as of right now this title is not worth it even on sale, just get the Batman games.

title: Gotham Knights
review: A game this focused on combat can't afford to have combat this shit. It's slow, it's sluggish, it's clunky, and worse than anything else it's deeply unsatisfying, a problem that comes as much from sound design as animation pacing.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Holy sh#t this game is frustrating, it's good AND bad in every aspects

-STORY-
The story starts great, we got introduced to Talia which has this kind of friendly but threatening vibe going around her, and you fight the cool villains such as Mr Freeze and Harley Quinn, but it took a nosedive near the end when the main antagonists became boring. Although, i love the main characters, especially Dick's relationship with Jason, they all very colorful in personality

-GRAPHICS-
The voice acting and the graphics are the best things i can say about the game, it's pretty and simple enough, but Gotham City looks a little bit generic and uninspired.

-GAMEPLAY-
I bet this is the thing that makes people has mixed opinion about this game, the combat is fun AFTER you unlocked several Abilities or upgrades with cool combos and animation, but the animations are cool, it's junky AS FUCK, but if you're patient enough, you're definitely going in on a good ride, until you realized that it's the same thing over and over again because as you gets stronger, so does the enemy, so the sense of progress is so disapproving.

It tries to introduce stealth, and it's very satisfying when me and my co-op friend execute a whole operation with only stealth, but it only happened like once or twice since it's very inconsistent with how the enemies will caught you, and the options to do stealth is VERY limited, so it gets repetitive in an already repetitive gameplay loop

-CONTROLS-
This is the most annoying thing of all, there's no forgiving in this, when your character needs to turn, it takes a second for them to twist their body, input delay is also a problem since you have to be quick to evades attack from the enemies, the parkour is slow but thanks to the grappling hook, it gets fun.

BUT THE F*CKING GLIDER, i play Nightwing most of the time and i tell you, his F*CKING GLIDER is A BIG HORSE.... RADISH, IT SUCKS, there are time trial challenges with the glider, and HOLY CRAP ARE THEY SUCKING BIG TOES, because the glider doesn't want you to go where you want to go, you touched a wall ? SORRY IDIOT, IT'S TIME FOR YOUR CHARACTER TO WALL JUMP, you touched a roof ? WELL, I GUESS YOU'RE WALKING NOW, and while you try to get back on air, the timer ends, this sh*t doesn't work at all, and the guy who came up with that, deserved to go to hell.

i was going recommend this game, but FUCK THE GLIDER, SUCK MY FUCKING DICK

1/10

title: Gotham Knights
review: Gotham Knights is a weird one. Story wise it was engaging and even the side missions were cool. Graphically looks decent and performance wise it ran great. Aside from the network issues with co-op lots of the time. Level gating to me made me enjoy it less unfortunately. Gameplay wise it was fine until you get to the point where you spam the X button to hit the people and it just gets boring. Also jumping/moving at all feels jank for me. Open world wise, not much happening there are crimes to do tho. It got pretty boring for me towards the end which is why I probably wouldn’t recommend it

title: Gotham Knights
review:
was a pretty fun superhero game until I got to the freeze boss fight. shit sucks dick. no I-frames on dodge make dodging shit in boss fights fucking terrible, and when you die it resets your entire fight. shit's fucking tragic. was having fun but I won't be playing after that boss fight becuase it is truly unplayable without being super overleveled. good luck doing the boss fight hitless. he has this on move where he goes to the edge of the map sometimes and then tracks you with a beam that he starts up after a short amount of time and if you get stuck against a wall, you garanteed dead because it's a stun that garantees a massive hit from him that will likely kill you. all becuase no i-frames during dodge.

also, no i-frames during cut-scene moves that you use in games, so if you want to do something cool like use your reload ability as redhood, don't, it's better to just do a regular reload that use the ability, and that's all the ability does, locks you into an animation where you reload where you can get hit and take full damage instead of just you reloading normally and being able to move around and dodge shit.

it has some really good bits but there's so much that's just been over looked, it's lacking some really basic things that most of these style of games have. I'm just lucky I got it from humble bundle with Sifu so this trainwreck doesn't cost me money

title: Gotham Knights
review: When your game is advertised as a co-operative stealth action game, maybe make sure your match making servers actually work. Been trying for the past half hour to link up with a friend that lives in the same household as me, on gigabit internet, how they thought this game would succeed with servers in this state is beyond me. Don't buy this if you want to play with friends, if you want to play solo, go for it

title: Gotham Knights
review: What surprise! Despite the mixed reviews, this game is really good! The graphics are great, the story is convincing, characters are fine and the gameplay's fun. After getting used to the awkward controls, you can quickly traverse the map and missions. The level design of most missions is exceptionally good for a coop-ready, story-driven narrative. Dialogue is cringy at times, but fits the general tone of the game. The fighting mechanic is engaging and it's fun to customize equipment and skills while including classic looting/leveling. Recommended, especially with coop campaign!

title: Gotham Knights
review: Looks like patching made this game better

title: Gotham Knights
review: Games super fun when it works imo, great that it has multiplayer as well. Getting to kick some butt alone or wit yo buddy is great. I recommend but when on sale just cause sales make everything even better.

It's online required, excessive loading, yeah, I'm going to go play something else. Maybe it's fun with a friend, I dunno but I doubt it tbh, the combat is pretty stale.

title: Gotham Knights

title: Gotham Knights
review:

P.S. I've played the Arkham series also & I still think GKs is a really worthy game in the superhero genre.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Yes, the performance issues were fixed. The game runs now smoothly on my GTX 1660 super; no frame drops whatsoever.

However, for me the problem is that the game became too repetitive too quickly. Combat did not really change that much, the grind was bland, and the random events that were generated were so basic and repetitive that you felt no sense of progression whatsoever.
For me, REPETITIVENESS killed the game. 

Better play something else!

title: Gotham Knights
review: super mid. the only fun thing about this game are the side missions and theres only 3 of those. main story is ass. If you want batfamily content just look up the cutscenes on youtube instead i swear it change anything

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I really, really liked this game. I played with a friend all the way through the story as soon as we could, and we had a blast. We did encounter the occasional glitch, along with some things game play wise that could definitely have used a bit of tweaking before the game's release. For example, there are some times where I'm trying to tell the character I'm playing as to grapple in a certain direction and they just won't, and it's common to get temporarily stuck on something or another player because you can collide into each other, even in small confined areas.

Despite the things previously mentioned, I loved the story told by this game, the characters, the music, the beautiful and atmospheric scenery and levels. It's extremely fun to play with a friend, going around the city and stopping crimes, fighting against various characters in the Batman rogue gallery, and exploring every corner of Gotham. 

As of right now, the reviews on the game seem to be mixed and it doesn't seem like it'll be changed anytime soon, and I completely understand because of the state the game was apparently released in, but in my opinion it's definitely worth playing now.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
First, I'd like to preface to everyone, this is NOT in anyway related to the Arkham series. Not in gameplay, nor story.

Now with that out of the way lets start with one subject that bothers a lot of people nowadays. DEI.
This game does have DEI in it, but not in a way that I think woke people would want. A lot of the criminals are women for some reason, which would be normal for the league of shadows but not every mob. And there are a few pride flags hidden around the place. The one in the belfry is on the top floor, an area you'll go to only for certain optional story segments, and a few references of pride parades in emails, that most people will not read. So on the DEI part of the game I'd say they just did the bare minimum to get their paycheck without affecting the game or story.

Gameplay: This isn't Arkham, as I said earlier. It does not have a slingshot combat system with an emphasis on countering attacks. It is more akin to a Spiderman game. You have your melee light/heavy attacks where heavy attacks end combos, And you have a light and heavy ranged attack where heavy has no combo but act as an AoE that can hit multiple enemies and dodging enemies. Other than that you can aim your ranged and dodge in a character specific manner.
Every character has their own skill sets that differentiate the way they play.
Nightwing is an acrobat so he jumps from target to target very quickly, having a special abilities promote this playstyle, such as an ability to pounce on an enemy, bounce and then grapple towards the next enemy.
Red-hood has a ranged playstyle, with greater aimed shot damage, better attack rate with range and abilities that allow him to unload his guns on anyone infront of him.
Batgirl is a more balanced fighter, using both her melee and ranged to great effect, using her grapple to bring enemies closer to her and having a variety of special abilities that do no focus on any single asspect of gameplay.
Robin is best at AoE and stealth, using his bo-staff to hit multiple enemies at once and quickly disappearing from combat. Being the only one who can stealth knockout large enemies and use perches to tie enemies up, Robin is amazing when stealth is your favorite aspect.

Talking of stealth... Since each character has a different playstyle, stealth may feel a bit off for certain characters. Everyone can sneak around, silently take down smaller opponents from any direction, be it from behind, hanging above them, below them or even while mid air or rushing them down quickly before they can alert anyone. But some characters aren't that great at it. Mainly being Red-hood. He is a lot clumsier, and can make you feel like something is really off with the stealth.
For example, every character can aim their ranged attack to attract an enemy to a certain location, but Red-hood uses guns which doesn't make much sense that the enemies will be attracted to the point of impact instead of the source of the gunshot. But hey, it still works...
And both Robin and Batgirl have special abilities for stealth that Nightwing and Red-hood don't have which increases the off feeling for stealth while playing them.
Overall, both the combat and stealth are quite satisfying and fun.

Story: The story of the game is servicable. it starts off with an awesome cutscene of batman fighting Ra's Al Ghoul, ending with the death of both and the call to action to our 4 heroes. The game is filled with beautifully made and choreographed cutscenes that are specific to the host player's character, meaning that the story can unfold with 4 variations. The story is still the same, but the attention to detail in the interactions between different characters and the different characters of the main cast is great to see, and IMO is sorely needed in other games that include multiple playable pre-made characters.
Other than that, the story falls to mediocraty due to the supporting cast.

Loot and progression: Now we're getting into one of the biggest controversy around this game. This game was planned to be a "games as a service" type game, and so it include loot and a rudamentry crafting system. And at first glance this system seems like it's important. That it may force you to play a single character and not allow you to enjoy everyone else, or that it will require grinding between story sections. But no, it's actually not that important. Levels are shared for all four heroes, and after every mission you get specific loot for all four characters that is usually better than what you can craft. It does affect end-game, where when you do "Heroic assault" This game's dungeon system, you will only get rewards for the specific character you played. Other than that, getting loot is easy, resources are plentiful, and other than a bit a of a drop in power for a few moments after selecting a different character, you come back really quickly.
The downside of this system is that it makes the difficulty of the game spike up and down really drastically.
The game uses a gearscore system, called power, that doesn't really tell you how good your gear is, but simply give an arbitrary number. A 300 power weapon can be weaker than a 100 power weapon, it all depends on the other stats. But the rest of the game follows the power system and adjusts according to that, so you may find yourself with over 1000 power but doing little damage, or the opposite, having 500 power but one-shotting everyone.
Also, enemies have their health and to a lesser degree, their damage, tied to their tier. Regular shooter can be one shot while a veteran may need a bit of a pounding. You'd expect that the level next to their health be a more accurate indicator of their power, but not really. Stealth, on the other hand, really balances things out since everyone KO's instantly to stealth, and grapple attacks do so much damage that they either insta KO or remove over half of any enemy's health-bar.

Traversal and Open-world: Gotham is a beautiful city, it has shanty-town like  slums, colorful streets with neon signs everywhere lighting up the smog and fog of the city. It has beautiful old sections lined with cobblestone and brick buildings, along the more modern streets with their clean and slick deisgnes. There's art in every corner of this city. Activities in the city are quite normal for open-world games these days. You got random crimes going on around. They can be mugging, attempts to break into buildings, beating up cops, etc. And there's the pre-maditated crimes, which can be more engaging. Bank robberies, Kidnapping, gang wars, etc. Other than that you get the regular activities. Collectibles and races, which we'll get into later.
The rest of Gotham might seem a bit dead. Certain areas are more densely populated than others, but you don't tend to see large groups of people or cars. But this can be explained with the high rate of criminality in Gotham. When passing civilians, some will be in awe of seeing you, most will be apathetic, while others will either shame you or get away from you hinting to the fact that they are likely criminals themselves. Which makes Gotham a dangerous place to walk around at night.

Now, how do you traverse Gotham city? Every one of the Bat-family has accesses to their own Motorcycle (batcycle) which can be speedy enough to go around, but after a completing a few early game challanges you can unlock a character specific movement system. Batgirl gets to glide like Batman speeding downwards and converting speed to upwards lift when needed. Robin gets to teleport short distances (I say short, but it's about 300 meters per jump). Nightwing gets a Jet Glider that allows him to fly at a constant rate. While Red-hood gets a mystical jump that allows him to jump on magic platforms in the air, prolonging the distance he can jump. Other than that, every character gets their own grapple to zip around the city, and small arenas.


Overall, the game is quite good

title: Gotham Knights
review:
TLDR: I Whish there was a neutral score, bc now i have to press the recommend button, but it's a 6/10 over-all.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The wokeam knights is a game where the lgbt bs is in every second character, except in the ones who should actually be gay (Montoya for example, according to the newest entry in the animated series, but questionable even then).

It feels like the game was made by people who actually never read a single comic in the DC universe. Also, if you wanna compare it to the Arkham franchise just keep scrolling, nothing 4 u here, bc it simply isn't that and it doesn't have to be.

But what it doesn't have to be either is tokenistic and inclusive. It's supposed to be a game for people who can deal with racism and inequality. Amen. Not the girly dudes, not your average women's rights acivist, but an adult person who undersands the world doesn't work in a way where everyone is equally accepted. Bc it's DC and DC is dark, it's unforgiving and not for the faint of heart. in Gotham, criminals prevail, bones are broken, people get killed and so on and gay people and women as big fighters apart from league of shadows are just not a thing. Even more so, those kind of people would get bullied even harder in Gotham lmao. It's funny how the majority of veteran fighters are female, like, the only accurate part is the shockwave a godmother causes when they jump and land on top of you. Yeah, u read right, god-mothers! Bruh ....

The cringy banter, the robin being an absolutely unbearable nerd (i like nerds, but not THIS kind of nerds), nightwing being just ok as always and redhood wanting to be menacing, but comes off like a try-hard every single time. Batgirl is also one of the more decent characters, but so anoying sometimes. Her one extremely redeeming feature is her ass and her combat style.

But brother, is the gameplay loop ever fun, if you have a buddy to play with. Simple, nothing over-the-top, loot-based, repetitive, but story-wise well paced and balanced. I fuck with the game, all the bs aside. Also all the suits are fucking awesome. Some really good hits and some unforgivable misses with this one. Buy at a deep discount, humble or instant gaming for even less.

title: Gotham Knights
review: It has the same problem for me like all of the BatMan games has.. the combat is too limited, no killing, too much stealth and too much talk.. gladly got it from Humble.. These games are not what I call action games.. Also have too low FPS even on low settings..

title: Gotham Knights
review: Game was pretty average. I come back sometimes because of decent combat and good co-op. There's some fun to be had, not at $60 though.

title: Gotham Knights

Gameplay gets a bit repetitive if you spend a lot of time in patrols but otherwise a fun time.

title: Gotham Knights
review:

Also, a pretty decent beat-em'-up that I'd recommend friends try with friends.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Gotham Knights Review (7.5/10)

Finally, a game where the Bat Family gets their time to shine! No more hiding in Batman’s shadow—now it's all about Nightwing’s flips, Batgirl’s brains, Red Hood’s, well… anger issues, and Robin’s stealthy tech skills. The game stays true to some of the comic-inspired costumes, so fans of the source material will get a kick out of that.

But let’s be honest, the UI looks like it was pulled from a high-end mobile game. I half-expected to see a "watch an ad for extra XP" button. Still, once you get past that, Gotham is as gorgeous as ever, and the gameplay has its moments of fun and chaos. It’s not a game-changer, but it’s a solid ride for DC fans.

Could it be better? Sure. Is it still worth saving Gotham with the Bat-family? Definitely.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Very Average, I could keep playing it but don't really want to.  Keyboard controls are not great.  Combat doesn't seem that great either.  I've played worse though.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Very good quality game to play just need a better quality cpu for the game myself other than that good game and would recommend to anyone

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Rating: 6.5/10
-------------------
This game is simply mediocre ... nothing is totally wrong ... nothing is great either.
If you get it very very cheap you can give it a try for a few hours ... just do not expect too much.

Slightly positive: story and technical aspects
-----------------------------------------------
Main story and story driven side missions are ok in general ... but also never more than that.
I also had no issues with performance or bugs at all ... seems like they have fixed most of it.
Graphics are ok ... but I have seen much better in similar and even much older games.

Mostly negative: actual gameplay
-------------------------------------
The uninspired loot system heavily drags this game down ... it feels pointless in this type of game.
The combat itself is ok at first but it gets really repetitive fast ... did not enjoy it much after a few hours.
Stealth is one of the most boring implementations I have seen in a while ... using stealth just makes the game slower and more tedious.
Open world feels lackluster ... exploration and side activities never really feel intresting.
Also the incredible slow travel speed is annoying ... the 50 mph on the motorbike is a joke.

Personal comments:
---------------------------
They should have focussed on just 1 character with more character depth instead of 4 shallow ones.
More focus on story and atmosphere instead of adding game mechanics that fans of the arkham series and other hero games absolutely do not care about would probably also have been wiser ...
Maybe a lot the issues in the game design are also caused by trying to make this a co-op game instead of a real single-player game.

-----

When playing I often felt like wasting time I could spend on better games ... not even sure if I will finish this.
Luckily I bought this on a 92% sale ... would have been truly annoyed if I had payed full price for it.

title: Gotham Knights
review: I mean, it's okay... but I played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City back in the day, and the combat in those felt like a whirling dance of death, somehow choreographed despite me being in full control of my actions, but the combat in Gotham Knights is just... lacklustre and repetitive. Apart from that, the game feels very tame like it's constantly on 'easy mode' trying to hold my hand the whole way, whilst also withholding certain crucial information through poor design rather than intentional tutorial escalation. The missions are annoying in that they only give you your sub-objectives whilst you're in combat... the driving feels very floaty compared to GTA and Cyberpunk... the satnav sometimes gets it wrong... the grappling hook travel is stop-and-start rather than Spiderman... and one time I was jumping my bat-bike through the air and misjudged an overhang that smashed Batgirl in the face at high speed but instead of being ripped off the bike and hurled backwards she didn't even notice. Disappointing, but at least I got it cheap in a Humble Bundle.

title: Gotham Knights

It is ok as a co-op experience, or if you really want another Batman game.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
It is not a bad game but it is plagued by time wasters that are not fun. It's worth sticking around for the story. Coop leaves much to be desired.

[spoiler] The end is horrendous. They had the chance to surprise us all with something good and a good continuation for a potential DLC with our beloved hero but that is not the case. They seemed to be super fixated on ending him for good. It is so sad [/spoiler]

title: Gotham Knights
review: It's god awful, it takes just a few minutes of gameplay to realise it's some kind of cheap copy of the Arkham games. It's hollow and bland, every gameplay mechanics has been dumbed down. Just stay really far away from this pile of trash.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
I had to read the EULA twice, on installation and when I started the game again. It's extremely long and explaines that they track what I do on my computer and that mods aren't allowed at all. It only started online, of course how would all that tracking work without internet? I had to read through a lot of meaningless nonsense after that, then there are extremely long meaningless video sequences. When I finally got to play the controls felt extremely clunky, and I have no freedom to do what I want. Go to this marker, hit e, go to this maker hit f, go to this maker hit shift... I'm not a bot.

I really don't want to be the party pooper, but this is how you take the fun out of games, I have seen this way too often with big publishers. I stick to indie games, this is the opposite of what fun looks like to me. I'm just glad to have those games in the Humble Bundle as a reminder every now and then.

Try Agents of Mayhem if you want something similar that feels like an actual game.

title: Gotham Knights
review: Average game, a delusion for those who expected way more having played Batman Games, but still a game worth to be played after all. The story is somehow intriguing and all the main story lines are fun to play, but all other activities through the map are repetitive and not really meaningful. City doesn't feel alive, just randomly filled with criminals and collectibles with emptyness all around. You are not going to have a good time moving around the map, it just feels very slow most of the time, even after you unlock teleports; driving mechanics for the motorcycle are too oversimplified and pathetic. Fighting mechanics is fun, but the experience is not going to change so much during the playthough resulting soon quite boring. GDR design for suit and weapons is totally unnecessary.

title: Gotham Knights
review: it's just a punch in your face if you like you get a new batman game. money crap, don't buy it!

title: Gotham Knights
review:
(I've beaten the game three times on PlayStation)

This game gets a lot of backlash, but me and my friend played it together and we genuinely had a fun time. He mained Robin, which is who I mained on my first playthrough (Solo), so it was cool playing the missions as other characters. This game definitely has some flaws though.

My biggest gripe with this game is the traversal, it feels extremely boring grappling/jumping around Gotham. There is a batcycle, but I feel like it should be a teeny bit faster than it is, not too much faster, but a tad bit faster would feel better imo. 
Another problem I feel I have with this game is how tanky the enemies feel when I'm fighting one even a single level above me, ESPECIALLY the brutes. The brutes with the shields are brutal to fight on any difficulty other than the easiest one when they're any level above me. Maybe it's just a skill issue, which would be likely since I'm still new to the RPG kind of games. 

I have some other complaints, but none that stand out from those two. I still had a ton of fun with this game, especially when I was playing it with my friend.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
This game wants to be a Batman Arkham game but it just isn't. I've tried all of the characters and none are particularly fun or good. It leans really hard on sending you all over an open world but is missing the fun of traversing around it in the way that batman could.

Maybe if you never played the Arkham games, and don't know what you are missing this one wouldn't feel so lacking.

title: Gotham Knights
review:
Despite everything, it’s still a Gotham city worth exploring.

I honestly love this game so far—id recommend waiting for discount prices, like I did. (Deeefinitely worth that -75%…)
